summary: In the Season 4 premiere, Vincent and Cat's wedded bliss is short-lived when J.T. brings them the news that someone is trying to expose the identities of beasts.
Cat and Vincent hunt a black marketeer of beasts; and try to protect an heiress whose identity was revealed.
Cat and Vincent's newlywed life is upended by lurking danger and they soon find themselves in the fight of their lives.

Cat investigates who's after Vincent and suspects that she may be pregnant. In other events, Vincent follows a lead that puts his life in jeopardy; and J.T. is kidnapped in a case of mistaken identity.
When Vincent and Cat are forced into hiding due to his being someone's target, he wonders what life would have been like for her without him in it—and gets a glimpse of just that.
Vincent and Cat learn that another nemesis is out to get Vincent; and their relationship is endangered when they wind up on opposite sides of the law.

Vincent and Cat regroup in their effort to bring down the beast hunters. To that end, Vincent tries to infiltrate a private army while Cat attempts to obtain information at work while hoping no one discovers her ulterior motives.
Vincent goes undercover with an operative whom Cat learns is an assassin; and Cat tries to prove to DHS that she can still be trusted.
Vincent and Cat strive to return normalcy to their lives despite the theats posed by a beast bounty and DHS manhunt; and Tess takes a risk by shielding Vincent from a reporter.
Vincent undergoes a series of tests arranged by the mystery buyer in order to not be exposed; and Cat, JT and Heather try to exonerate Vincent.

In the Season 3 premiere, Vincent considers popping the question. The timing may not be right, however, when Cat stumbles upon an unusual case involving a superhuman rampage. In other events, Tess believes JT--who doesn't understand how he's still alive--has a mental block to recovery.

Vincent moves in with Cat; and they follow a new lead in their investigation of the super-human experiments. In other events, J.T. tries to impress Tess' brothers; and Heather returns to town with a surprise announcement.

Cat and Vincent team with married FBI agents on a case; J.T. thinks he may possess super powers; Tess contemplates a career move; and Heather makes a suggestion that could make her big sister's life a little easier.
Cat and Vincent see a therapist about their relationship; and Cat investigates a wealthy transplant recipient whom she suspects may be behind the mysterious experiments.

Cat is assigned to a new partner; and comes to suspect that Bob and Carol are working to separate her from Vincent. In other events, JT learns that his newfound healing ability comes with a high price.

JT arranges a surprise bachelor party for Vincent, but the fun is cut short by a sniper who's out to end Vincent and Cat's interference with the super human experiments. In other events, Cat's family comes to town for her bridal shower; and Cat visits her imprisoned father to ask for his help.

An assassin targets Cat and Vincent, who attempt to lure him out of town and away from their loved ones by pretending that they're going to elope; and JT, who's tired of being under police protection, asks Tess to help him track down a lead. A distracted Heather, meanwhile, tries to focus on her new job.

Cat's thrilled about her pending nuptials, but is distracted by the notion that the rash of superhuman experiments could ruin her big day, so Vincent, JT and Tess do their best to keep her eyes on the prize.
Vincent, Tess and Heather try to boost Cat's spirits after the events of her big day leave her doubtful that they can defeat the threat.
Cat and Vincent set out to capture Liam; and come across information that could help them do just that. In other events, JT and Tess work to confirm that JT is serum-free.
Gabe has recovered and Catherine is still obsessed with finding Vincent.
New and exclusive hit US series where mystery meets fantasy. Cat searches for information about Vincent's mission but she gets a little too close to the truth.
Cat and Vincent follow an unusual beast. Tess tries to find out why Gabe is helping Cat.
Cat attempts to distance herself from Gabe, and he asks Vincent for some assistance.
Cat finds out more about her past at her high school reunion. An old friend meets up with Vincent.
Cat confronts her father (Ted Whittall). Meanwhile, Vincent rescues Tori (Amber Skye Noyes).
Cat invites Vincent to spend thanksgiving with her in order to protect him.
New and exclusive hit US series where mystery meets fantasy. Cat and Vincent disagree about the best way to deal with Agent Reynolds. Vincent doubts his humanity.

Kristin Kreuk, Sendhil Ramamurthy, Austin Basis, Jay Ryan, Nina Lisandrello. New and exclusive hit US series where mystery meets fantasy. Cat protects Tori, attempting to stop Vincent from acquiring more injuries. Gabe and Cat bond.
Cat goes undercover for the FBI. Later, she comes face-to-face with Vincent during a heist.
After witnessing her mother's murder, a female detective is saved by a supposed beast.
When a ballerina is murdered, Cat investigates, with some help from Vincent.
Cat investigates the murder of a judge after Vincent tells her that the main suspect is innocent.
Cat is asked to trade in Vincent in exchange for information about her mother's death.
After he prevents a robbery, Vincent's photo appears in the newspapers.
Cat investigates the murder of an artist whose work was being used as a front for an escort service.
Evan finds a strange cut on a victim's ankle which matches that of a body left on campus a year ago.
Vincent's memories of being experimented on in Afghanistan resurface when he is injected with chemicals.
The hit US series where mystery meets fantasy. Cat invites Vincent to be her date for her father's wedding where she makes a startling discovery.
The US series where mystery meets fantasy. Cat struggles with her feelings for Vincent in hospital while Vincent himself is in danger of being unmasked.
This episode from the television fantasy series of the '80s deals with the kidnapping of the beauty Catherine by a malevolent crime boss and how her beloved beastial Vincent comes to her rescue.

Conclusion. During her captivity, Catherine learns a breathtaking fact. Stephen McHattie. Vincent: Ron Perlman. Elliot Burch: Edward Albert. Moreno: Bill Marcus. Manning: Richard Roundtree. Pascal: Armin Shimerman.

An NYPD investigator begins her work on Catherine's case, while Vincent collects his thoughts and realizes what his course of action should be. Joe: Jay Acovone. Elliot Burch: Edward Albert. Jenny: Terri Hanauer. Mark: Lewis Smith.

Vincent contacts Elliot and reveals their mutual connection to Catherine, and Elliot in turn encourages Joe to keep investigating the case. Gabriel: Stephen McHattie. Manning: Richard Roundtree. Morneo: Bill Marcus. Fitch: M. Scott Wilkinson. Diana: Jo Anderson. Vincent: Ron Perlman.

Gabriel hires an icy assassin to hunt down the wounded Vincent, while Diana takes her first peek at the tunnels. Snow: Lance Henriksen. Brooke: Laurel Moglen. Stephen: Randy Kaplan. Pascal: Armin Shimerman. Vincent: Ron Perlman.

Vincent continues his quest for vengeance against Gabriel, who offers Elliot a chance to regain his wealth and power by betraying Vincent; Diana (Jo Anderson) keeps a vigil by Catherine's grave, hoping to spot Vincent. Walker: Stanley Kamel. Det. Hughs: John Michael Bolger.

Diana meets Vincent face to face as she aids in his recuperation, while Father contacts Joe after he resolves to go above and find Vincent. Mark: Lewis Smith. Jorge: Daniel Faraldo. Mary: Ellen Geer. Brooke: Laurel Moglen.

After she looks for clues about the ring, Diana is captured by Gabriel, who directs her to tell Vincent that his son is dying. Pope: John Lehne. Doctor: Kenneth Kimmins. Rebecca: Kathryn Spitz. Martin: Steven Gilborn. Diana: Jo Anderson. Vincent: Ron Perlman.

Gabriel has imprisoned Vincent, who alone holds the power to save his son, while Father helps Diana and Joe attempt a climactic rescue. Father: Roy Dotrice. Doctor: Kenneth Kimmons. Pope: John Lehne. Sammy: Tony Maggio.

The plight of a friend addicted to heroin sends Vincent on a rampage against a drug lab belonging to the evil Gabriel (Stephen McHattie). Rolley: Terrance Ellis. Horner: Tony Plana. Joe: Jay Acovone. Diana: Jo Anderson. Father: Roy Dotrice. Susan: Suzie Plakson.

Vincent and Catherine try to salvage a piano prodigy, once sheltered in the tunnels, who turned to drugs after a personal tragedy. Ron Perlman, Linda Hamilton. Rolley (age 11): Garland Spencer. Miss Kendrick: Janet MacLachlan. Eli: Theodore Bikel.

An angel shows Vincent that life without him would not be so wonderful for the people he loves, especially Catherine (Linda Hamilton). Roy Dotrice, David Greenlee. Paracelsus: Tony Jay. Pascal: Armin Shimerman. Jamie: Irina Irvine.

Vincent brings an ailing Soviet seaman to the tunnels, where it's learned that the man is carrying a plague. Ron Perlman, Linda Hamilton, Roy Dotrice. Dr. Alcott: Joseph Campanella. Ellie: Kamie Harper. Eric: Joshua Rudoy.
Paracelsus, disguised as one of the guests at Winterfest, has explosive plans for disrupting the festivities. Ron Perlman, Linda Hamilton. Dr. Alcott: Joseph Campanella. Narcissa: Beah Richards.

Catherine brings an ex-prostitute about to give birth down to the tunnels, where she falls in love with Vincent. Linda Hamilton, Ron Perlman. Mary: Ellen Geer. Maurice: Willard E. Pugh. Lady: Dendrie Taylor. Samantha: Marcie Leeds.

A deaf woman raised in the tunnels but living above joins a gang whose violent leader Catherine wants apprehended. Jerry: Ron Marquette. Lincoln: Ed Kelly. William: Ritch Brinkley. Rebecca: Kathryn Spitz.

Catherine welcomes a young man from the tunnel world who's pursuing his education, which includes bitter lessons about life and love. Linda Hamilton, Ron Perlman. Michael's Father: John-Frederick Jones. Tina: Riad. Brooke: Laurel Moglen.
Vincent and the tunnel dwellers must decide whether a teenager who discovers the tunnel world can keep it a secret. Linda Hamilton, Ron Perlman. Edward: Daniel Benzali. Old Man: Robert Cornthwaite.

A deformed man escapes from his life as a carnival freak with the help of a former tunnel dweller, and Vincent offers a sympathetic hand to the suffering man. Ron Perlman, Linda Hamilton. Devin: Bruce Abbott. Eddie: Don Stark. Bernie: Robert Britton.

Catherine faces an ethical dilemma when a woman recognizes a respected family man from the tunnels as the man who was charged with the death of her son 16 years ago. Linda Hamilton. Kanin: Scott Jaeck. Olivia: Elayne Heilveil.

This made-for-television movie was the pilot for the series Beauty and the Beast. An attorney (Linda Hamilton) in New York City has her life saved by a huge, deformed but gentle man-beast named Vincent (Ron Perlman). Vincent, not wishing to live among "normal" people, lives in the underground tunnels beneath the city. Against their better judgment, the two start falling in love with each other.

A beast-like vigilante is killing subway criminals and Cathy suspects Vincent (Ron Perlman). Father: Roy Dotrice. Jason Walker: Dorian Harewood. Mrs. Dalby: Tracee Lyles. Suki: Iilana B'tiste. Red: Anthony Peck.

Vincent's heart begins to break when Catherine gets involved with a wealthy bachelor until the case she's on starts to bend cupid's arrow. Vincent: Ron Perlman. Micha Langer: Albert Hague. Mundy: Louis Giambalvo.

Vincent is wounded and trapped above ground when Catherine (Linda Hamilton) is caught in a cross-fire during a gang war. Chris: Chris Nash. Howie: Tony Longo. Lucy: Nancy Lenehan. Shake: Merritt Butrick.

Vincent slips into a masquerade fund-raiser for an Irish peace activist with plenty of enemies---some of whom are hiding behind masks. Charles Chandler: John McMartin. McPhee: Gerry Gibson. Donald: Eric Pierpoint.

A childhood friend (Asher Brauner) of Vincent's is released from prison, and Cathy (Linda Hamilton) looks into his dealings, unaware that his lust for power endangers her life. Sweeney: Stan Kamber. De Corsia: Michael Pniewski. Vincent: Ron Perlman. Father: Roy Dotrice.
Catherine agonizes over a plum job offer in another state---until two ambitious anthropologists capture Vincent (Ron Perlman). Hughes: Michael Ensign. Gould: Christian Clemenson.

An ad in the personals column summons Father above ground, where he walks into a Kafkaesque nightmare and is arrested for murder. Margaret: Diana Douglas. Dutton: Paul Gleason. Taft: Robert Symonds. Catherine: Linda Hamilton.

Voodoo artists cast a killing spell on members of the business community, drawing Catherine into their black magic and turning her against Vincent. Lindsay: Diana Barton. Ross: Cliff De Young. Narcissa: Beah Richards. Vincent: Ron Perlman.

Foster children are disappearing and, when one of the tunnel kids witnesses the abuse of a young runaway, Vincent calls on Catherine to investigate. Ron Perlman, Linda Hamilton. Richard Barnes: Richard Herd. Naj: Richard Portnow. Kipper: Cory Danziger. Father: Roy Dotrice.
The Ballet West dancers return from winter break and begin tryouts for "Cinderella."
A foot infection slows Ronnie down; Rex begins to see improvement with his torn tendon; and Beckanne and Chase confront Zach about rumors they believe he started.
Casting decisions are announced; Allison ponders retirement; and Joshua has a heart-to-heart with Adam.
Allison gets unexpected news from Adam; Christiana and Chris hit a rough patch in their marriage.
With contract renewals around the corner, the rivalry between Zach and Ian continues as they fight for a spot in the main company.

The dancers focus their attention on the opening night of "Cinderella." Meanwhile, Allison turns to Rex when she doesn't get the support she needs from Jonathan; Beckanne returns to her former ballet school in Philadelphia to seek guidance; and Christiana suffers an injury that puts everyone on edge.
Rex battles a foot injury; Jonathan makes Allison anxious.
With closing night of "Cinderella" just around the corner, the dancers continue to give it all they've got.
With closing night behind them, the dancers head to Los Angeles for a fundraiser.

The cutthroat world of competitive ballet is spotlighted at the Ballet West company in Salt Lake City. In the opener, a behind-the-scenes look offers a glimpse into the unglamorous side of a professional ballet company.
Ronald faces a tough decision on his dancing future; Katie auditions for other ballet companies; and Adam plans an erotic ballet.
Allison struggles while training under a well-known Russian choreographer; Beckanne deals with resentment and jealousy after being promoted; and Katie auditions for other ballet companies.
Beckanne outperforms Allison and Ronnie during rehearsals; Rex confronts Allison about their relationship status; and Ronnie's sister visits Salt Lake City.
The dancers prepare for opening night; Beckanne and Katie go on a double date with the Tilton brothers; Allison receives unwanted advice from her family.
The dancers voice concern about Rex's fall on opening night; Christiana gets into a heated argument with her husband; and Rex clashes with Allison.
In the 12th season premiere, the gang turn black after an electric blanket shorts out, so they engage in body switching antics they've seen the movies to change themselves back.
The gang visit a waterpark and Dennis gets a protégé; Charlie and Frank try to ride all the rides by any means necessary; and Mac and Dee get stuck in a tube slide.

The gang create a sitcom using spy cameras originally installed out of fear that Charlie's Mom was holding Mac's mom hostage. Later: Dee wants in on the new project and Frank becomes obsessed with Charlie's mom.

Frank hits PR trouble due to a news segment that names Wolf Cola the official drink of Boko Haram, so Dee and Dennis help manage the crisis while Charlie and Mac try to plan a way to make Fight Milk the official drink of the UFC.
A cat-woman is killed and Dennis becomes the main suspect.
The gang fight over a lottery ticket and seek out an arbitrator to decide a rightful owner, who also decides if Frank is a hero or hate monger.
Dee dates a male stripper and tries to prove her worth after learning she's his "rock bottom." Elsewhere: Mac and Frank get sucked into a VR war game, leading Mac to develop a case PTSD.

Dennis asks the gang to work at Paddy's during Valentine's Day, but they get distracted by a mystery cricket hanging out in the alley. Later: they realize Dennis wants them to improve their relationships and they air their grievances.
A day in Cricket's world is spotlighted.
In the 12th season finale, Dennis reveals he has a baby after his Wade Boggs layover in North Dakota and the gang try to help him get out of the jam, but their suggestions border on the extreme.
In the 11th season premiere, the gang agree to a truce and demonstrate Chardee MacDennis for an interested board game executive, but things quickly go off the rails.
Frank falls out of a window and his injury makes him think it's 2006, so the gang use it as a chance to correct past mistakes.
Dennis and Frank battle Dee and Mac for control of the mountain and Charlie learns the rules of the slopes.
Dennis makes a movie spotlighting his erotic memoirs while Frank and Mac try to pass off Charlie as a gifted artist to make money.
Mac and Dennis move to the suburbs for cheaper rent but find it hard to adjust.
The gang have a new scheme and Frank tries to keep up.
Old grievances surface when the Lawyer sues Bill Ponderosa on behalf of Liam McPoyle and his lost eye.
Dennis wants to build a mobile Paddy's pub experience, but runs into trouble when customers refuse to cooperate. Elsewhere: Charlie and Mac try to catch a thieving leprechaun.
Part 1 of 2. The gang go on a cruise to escape their usual dynamic, but find it difficult to break old habits.
Conclusion. The gang encounter danger and get real with each other.
The gang try to break a legendary beer-drinking record in the Season 10 premiere.
The online-dating scene is explored by the gang.
The gang is divided when Psycho Pete is released from the mental hospital.
A surprise health inspection puts the gang in a bind.
Suspicions grow within the gang as Dennis, Mac and Dee spy on a fish factory.
The gang become introspective as they try to figure out who they really are.
Mac attempts to clear his dad's name in a murder case.
The gang compete on a televised game show.
Frank decides to retire, setting off a power struggle among the gang for control of Paddy's.
In the Season 10 finale, a new exercise craze may be more than meets the eye.
Dee's stand-up comedy career takes off in the 9th Season premiere.
The gang debate gun ownership.
The gang seek recognition for their years of service in the bar industry.

The gang does their best to recoup their investments in questionable schemes by dumping their losses on Ben the soldier while trying to avoid being duped again by whatever mastermind is pulling their strings. -- (C) FX
The gang do what Mac wants on his special day.
The gang get caught in the middle of an armed robbery.
The flu breaks out in Philadelphia, prompting the gang to quarantine themselves.
The gang are left in a bind when Charlie leaves his job at the bar.
Creative differences arise while the gang produce a movie.
The gang make amends with old foes in the Season 9 finale.

Presented by FX. Dennis and Dee's ailing grandfather Pop-Pop is wasting away in the hospital, and they have to decide whether or not to pull the plug. But things get complicated when The Gang learns of Pop-Pop's history as a Nazi.
The gang eye a trash-collecting contract with the city of Philadelphia after the town's garbage collectors go on strike.

Presented by FX. When Charlie and Dee invade the rarefied world of the 1%, they find a romantic connection with two members of one of Philly's wealthiest families. Mac, Dennis and Frank try to get a piece of the action.
The gang visit a therapist, who finds Dennis' psychology to be abnormal.
Presented by FX. In perhaps the most depraved scheme of them all, The Gang rallies around Charlie's mom as she battles cancer.
Frank helps his old company complete a merger. Meanwhile, the gang gets caught up in a case of mistaken identity.
The gang develops an unhealthy obsession with video games.
The gang go out to celebrate at an upscale restaurant.
Frank and Dennis hold court at Paddy's Pub.

Presented by FX. "Sweet Dee Gets Audited." Desperate times call for truly sad and horrific measures as Sweet Dee tries to get out of an IRS audit. The rest of The Gang institutes a new democratic voting system.
Presented by FX. "Frank's Brother." The Gang is shocked to meet Frank's long lost brother, Gino, when he unexpectedly arrives at Paddy's Pub and exposes a wealth of family secrets.
Presented by FX. "The Storm of the Century." With an apocalyptic storm headed to Philly, The Gang joins the panicking masses in a race to secure scarce resources.
Presented by FX. "Chardee MacDennis: The Game of Games." What's The Gang to do on a rainy day but play the most twisted (and self-made) board game ever.

Presented by FX. "The ANTI-Social Network." After an annoying bar patron enrages The Gang, Mac and Dee take to the internet to cyber-stalk their prey, while Dennis and Charlie track him the old-fashioned way.

Presented by FX. This season, tune in to see the Gang prepare for the apocalypse, hit the beach at the Jersey Shore, produce a child beauty pageant, and take a walk down memory lane at their high school reunion.
Presented by FX. "The High School Reunion." The gang attends their high school reunion with a lot to prove. Old friends are met and new foes are made as the gang trips down memory lane.
Conclusion. In the Season 7 finale, the gang come up with a new plan to buff their tarnished high-school reputations at their high-school reunion.
Mac pulls out the big guns to protect the sanctity of marriage, while the rest of the gang reap the rewards of marital bliss.
Marital bliss turns into business, as the gang experiences the emotional and economic hardships of divorce.
The gang attempts to find adventure on the sea after they purchase their 'new' boat.
Mac finally gets his big break after correctly answering a trivia question on the radio; Frank, Dennis, and Dee take their bar-banter to the internet with their own podcast.
Mac and Charlie try to fix up an abandoned pool in order to beat the heat wave; Dennis and Dee try to beat the heat in a more 'dignified' and 'upper-class' way.
Charlie and Mac set-up a truly odd couple after Mac's Mom burns the house down; Frank discovers the importance of paternal care when Dee falls ill.

Dee's pregnant, and she tells the guys that one of them made her that way during a Halloween party that none of them can remember. So they try to piece the evening together, "Potemkin"-style, aided by Artemis (Artemis Pebdani) and the McPoyle brothers (Nate Mooney and Jimmi Simpson).
A blast from the past prompts the guys to expand membership and Dee to re-consider her future.
Dee takes a job as a substitute teacher and exposes her students to the culture of Paddy's with a field trip to see the Gang's take on the Lethal Weapon series.
Keeping the basement rodent-free drives Charlie to the brink; the gang throws Charlie a surprise party.

The Madonna of Paddy's? The gang seeks financial salvation when a leaky pipe at Paddy's causes a water stain on the wall that resembles the Virgin Mary. Meanwhile, Dee has an awkward reunion with a priest (David Hornsby) who had a crush on her in high school.
The gang take a road trip. Destination: the Grand Canyon.
With a shantytown taking shape outside, Mac and Dennis try to keep Paddy's going in tough times. Meanwhile, Frank and Dee start a family business.
Frank's behavior is more bizarre than usual---so bizarre that even the gang notice---so they decide to stage an intervention.
The Waitress (Mary Elizabeth Ellis) is getting married, and Dee's jealous because she isn't. Meanwhile, the guys try to get the lovelorn Charlie back ;into the dating scene.
The gang go to court to talk their way out of a parking ticket they got on the night of the final game of the 2008 World Series.
The gang stages a wrestling show for returning troops. Meanwhile, Dee meets a soldier she's been talking to online; but he isn't what she expected. Da' Maniac: Roddy Piper.
With a merchandising convention in town, the gang tries to build the Paddy's brand by developing marketable products---such as mittens for kittens.
Mac and Dennis decide to take a break from each other, a development that strains relationships. Meanwhile, "kitten mitten" Charlie helps Dee find her lost cat.
Dennis tells the gang how he seduces women, but none of them can get the hang of it.

In the Season 4 premiere, Dee and Charlie eat some of Frank's stash of extraordinarily tasty meat and won't rest until they can get more. Meanwhile, Mac and Dennis take sport hunting to the next level.

Mac, Dennis, and Charlie take advantage of high gas prices by investing in barrels of gasoline and selling them door-to-door; Dee and Frank plot to brand Bruce Mathis as a terrorist leader when they find out that he plans to give their money to a Muslim community center.
Mac and Frank judge a contest to determine Paddy's next top model; Dee and Charlie strive to come up with YouTube's next sensation.
Charlie wants Mac to beat up the waitress's unknown new boyfriend. Trouble is, Mac is the boyfriend.
After Mac's revenge-obsessed father is released from prison, Mac and Charlie fake their deaths to save their lives. Frank, Dee and Dennis find unique ways of dealing with the loss of the guys.

Conclusion. Frank, Dee and Dennis find unique ways of dealing with the loss of Mac and Charlie. The guys faked their deaths to avoid Mac's vengeance-obsessed father (Gregory Scott Cummins), who was released from prison.

Frank and Charlie find that someone has soiled their bed, and Mac and Dennis join them as they attempt to catch the culprit. Meanwhile, Dee leads Artemis and the waitress on a Sex and the City-style night on the town.
The gang kidnaps a newspaper critic after he calls Paddy's "the worst bar in Philadelphia."
Mac and Frank find Dennis' erotic memoir and attempt to profit from it, while Dee and Charlie spend a day in each other's shoes.
After Dee suffers a heart attack, she and Dennis try to live a healthier lifestyle. Meanwhile, Charlie and Mac take corporate jobs to get health insurance.

Dennis is trying to get in good with a local environmental group when he snubbed by the activists who think he's just a suburban poseur. Later, as Dennis schemes to seduce the group leader's pretty girlfriend, Mac and Dee discover a dumpster baby and try to turn the infant into a child star, and Charlie and Frank become obsessed with the concept of recycling.

The Philadelphia Eagles are holding open tryouts, and while Mac, Dennis, and Dee drag their personal conflicts out onto the gridiron, Frank and Charlie opt for the tailgate party but run into trouble with the McPoyles.

Barbara has died suddenly, but is there anything in her will for Frank and Dee? Upon discovering that they've gotten the shaft from the recently deceased, the disgruntled duo teams up to take revenge against Barbara. Meanwhile, Dennis has inherited every square inch of his mother's sprawling estate. But what good is living in a mansion when you realize that you and all of circle of friends are going to die alone and forgotten? If the gang could only figure out how to make some new friends perhaps they'd be able to avoid such a grim fate.

The feud between the gang and the McPoyles finally boils over when the greasy-haired brothers and their incestuous sister take everyone hostage in Paddy's. But what the McPyoles have failed to realize is that Frank has crawled into the ventilation system in hopes of tracking down his will. As the situation intensifies, a little man up in the ceiling becomes the gang's only hope for a safe escape.

When Dee realizes that the biggest, fattest loser from her graduating class has become a beautiful and successful fashion designer, the realization that she herself is now the biggest loser proves something of a rude awakening.

Paddy's has always been the most profitable stop on the pub crawl due to its prime location, so when a Korean restaurateur with a killer microbrew sets up shop just a block away, the gang declares war. As the pub crawl draws near, Charlie strikes up a romance with a young Korean waitress.

The gang has received an offer that's too good to pass up, and now they're prepared to sell Paddy's. Now, as a result, Charlie and Dee will have to find real jobs. After securing a job at a popular chain restaurant in town, the responsibility-shirking duo quickly proves that they are incapable of functioning in a normal work environment.
In a bid to become local celebrities, the gang creates a public access show catering to the local nightclub crowd.

Dee has fallen in love with a local rapper, but is he really mentally retarded like the rest of the gang claims? Meanwhile, the rest of the gang realizes that if Dee's mentally deficient boyfriend can be a successful musician they could pull together and form a pretty decent band of their own.

There's a serial killer running loose in Philadelphia, and Mac has been exhibiting some pretty bizarre behavior as of late. When the gang begins to suspect that Mac is behind the murders, they cook up a plan to catch him red handed. But Charlie believes that Mac is innocent, and he's ready to use all the legal knowledge he's gained from watching television to prove it. Later, when the gang learns the true cause for Mac's bizarre behavior, the reality of the situation proves far more disturbing than any fictional scenario they could dream up.

Charlie is rendered wheelchair-bound following a nasty accident, and as the gang attempts to figure out how to get the most mileage out of their recently-crippled friend Dennis and Dee's estranged father Frank (Danny DeVito) makes an attempt to reconnect with his long lost children.

The owner of the bar next door stops by Paddy's to announce that his property line reaches right to the middle of their establishment, and as a result half of the bar will be demolished. Later, as the gang resorts to extremes in order to save the bar, Frank discovers that his wife is in town.

Frank has become too much to handle, leaving Dennis and Dee with no other option than to quit their jobs and go on welfare. As a result, the weight that Dennis and Dee would help to carry is shifted directly over to Mac and Charlie.
After Barbara hook up with Dennis in an attempt to make Frank jealous, Dennis becomes obsessed with the idea of revenge through bedding Mac's mom.

Dee has been mugged, and now Frank is going to teach his daughter how to box so she can defend herself on the streets. Upon arriving at the gym, Frank spots his old boxing adversary and an old rivalry is reignited for the next generation. Meanwhile, Dennis and Mac scheme to make some quick cash by entering Charlie into an underground fighting competition.

The gang is arrested for arson and sentenced to community service. Meanwhile, as Frank tries to reestablish a bond with Dennis, Charlie begins attending AA meetings in hopes of getting better acquainted with his favorite waitress.

When the gang discovers a stain on the office wall that bears an uncanny resemblance to the Virgin Mary, Charlie, Dennis, and Frank scheme to exploit the Biblical blemish for all its worth. Mac and Dee have serious reservations about the scam, and later Dee runs into a person from the past who stirs forbidden feelings deep within her.
When Frank displays a profound insight into politics, Dennis decides to run for office under his father's guidance.

An argument over the constitution has led the gang to run Paddy's as an establishment where moral and behavioral boundaries no longer exist. Meanwhile, Frank takes advantage of the situation by opening a dangerous gambling ring in the bar, and Charlie attempts to display his love for America by performing on the street with Dee - who uses the situation as an opportunity to display her finely tuned acting skills.

When Dee receives a message from a man claiming to be her real father, she and Dennis rejoice at the idea that they may not be Frank's offspring after all. Meanwhile, Mac pays a long overdue visit to his father, who is currently serving an extended prison sentence.

In the premiere episode of FX's raunchy sitcom It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, the viewer is introduced to Paddy's Irish Pub co-owners Mac (Rob McElhenney), Charlie (Charlie Day), Dennis (Glenn Hoowerton), and Dennis' sister Dee (Kaitlin Olson). Lately, the business at Paddy's hasn't been so good, and the gang is eager to bring in some new clientele. Realizing that the best way of increasing their profile is to advertise, the owners of Paddy's agree to hire Dee's acting friend Terrell as their new spokesman. Later, after Charlie and Mac make some insensitive remarks that smack of racism, the pair launches a concerted effort to prove that they aren't prejudice.

A girl from Charlie's past appears claiming that the pair once had a child and it's time for Charlie to take responsibility. Meanwhile, Mac and Dennis head out to an anti-abortion rally in hopes of meeting some girls.

Realizing the potential for profit in tapping the elusive underage drinking market, the gang lowers the legal drinking age at Paddy's under the guise of providing youngsters with a safe place to get plastered. Later, after Dee begins dating a popular high school jock, Charlie, Mac, and Dennis do their best to score a date for the upcoming prom.

Mac and Dennis are convinced that Charlie has cancer, and in order to ease their old friend's anguish they try and find a girl to sleep with him. As the search for a willing woman intensifies, Mac falls for a pretty transsexual named Carmen and Dee tries convincing Dennis that they need more help at the bar.

The safe in the bar has been stolen, prompting Dennis and Mac to purchase a pistol and go gunning for the thief. Meanwhile, Charlie's disgruntled landlord attempts to collect rent and Dee feigns interest in firearms in order to connect with her smarmy boyfriend Colin.

Smitten with the pretty granddaughter of a patron who recently died while drinking at Paddy's, Mac and Dennis pretend that they were close friends with the old man. Meanwhile, Dee attempts to overcome her intense fear of senior citizens by dragging Charlie along to visit her grandfather in the nursing home.

The gang's former elementary school teacher has just been accused of molesting a student, and in the wake of that revelation Charlie becomes especially sensitive. Meanwhile, Mac deals with the announcement in his own peculiar way as Dennis and Dee argue over how to help Charlie.
